change.summary: The proposed amendment allows an enforcement order to require the respondent to publish the order and a corrective statement.

change.subject: subsection 9
change.quote: (9) An undertaking under subsection (5) may include a further undertaking by the respondent to publish— (a) the terms of the undertaking; (b) a corrective statement.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows an undertaking under subsection (5) to include a further undertaking by the respondent to publish the terms of the undertaking and a corrective statement.

change.subject: subsection 10
change.quote: (10) Publication under subsection (8) or (9)— (a) must be made in such form and manner, and to such extent, as the court considers appropriate for the purpose of eliminating any continuing effects of the conduct in respect of which the order was made or undertaking given; (b) is not an enhanced consumer measure for the purposes of this Chapter. 5
change.summary: The proposed amendment specifies that publication under subsection (8) or (9) must be made in a form and manner determined by the court to eliminate any continuing effects of the conduct, and it is not considered an enhanced consumer measure.

change.subject: section 150
change.quote: 150 Enforcement orders and undertakings: enhanced consumer measures 15 (1) An enforcement order or undertaking may include a requirement to take such enhanced consumer measures as the court considers just and reasonable.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows an enforcement order or undertaking to include a requirement to take enhanced consumer measures as determined by the court.

change.subject: section 151
change.quote: 151 Enforcement orders: requirement to pay monetary penalty 5 (1) This section applies where the court makes an enforcement order against the respondent on an application made by a public designated enforcer. (2) The order may, subject to subsection (3), include a requirement for the respondent to pay a monetary penalty.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows an enforcement order to include a requirement for the respondent to pay a monetary penalty.

change.subject: section 152
change.quote: 152 Interim enforcement orders and undertakings 30 (1) This section applies if— (a) it is alleged in an application under section 146 for an interim enforcement order that a person (“the respondent”)— (i) 35 has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice which constitutes a relevant infringement (“the infringing practice”), or (ii) is an accessory to the infringing practice, (b) it appears to the court that if the application had been an application for an enforcement order it would be likely to be granted, and Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Bill 97 Part 3—Enforcement of consumer protection law Chapter 3—Consumer protection orders and undertakings (c) the court considers it is expedient that the infringing practice is prohibited or prevented immediately. (2) The court may— (a) make an interim enforcement order against the respondent, or (b) accept an undertaking from the respondent to comply with subsection 5 (5) or to take steps which the court believes will secure such compliance.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows the court to make an interim enforcement order or accept an undertaking from the respondent if it is alleged that the respondent has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement and the court considers it necessary to prohibit or prevent the practice immediately.

change.subject: section 153
change.quote: 153 Applications (1) The CMA may apply to the appropriate court for an online interface order, 5 or an interim online interface order, if the CMA considers that a person has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement. (2) An application for an online interface order, or an interim online interface order, may be made in respect of— (a) 10 the person that the CMA considers has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement, or (b) any other person (subject to subsection (3)).
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows the CMA to apply for an online interface order or an interim online interface order if they believe a person has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement.

change.subject: section 154
change.quote: 154 Online interface orders 30 (1) The court may make an online interface order on an application under section 153 if the court finds that— (a) a person has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement, (b) there are no other available means under this Chapter of bringing 35 about the cessation or prohibition of the infringement which, by themselves, would be wholly effective, and (c) it is necessary to make the order to avoid the risk of serious harm to the collective interests of consumers.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows the court to make an online interface order if it finds that a person has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement, there are no other effective means to stop the infringement, and it is necessary to protect the collective interests of consumers.

change.subject: section 155
change.quote: 155 Interim online interface orders (1) The court may make an interim online interface order against a person (“the 25 respondent”) on an application under section 153 if— (a) it is alleged that there has been or is likely to be a relevant infringement, (b) 30 it appears to the court that if the application had been an application for an online interface order it would be likely to be granted, and (c) the court considers it expedient to bring about the cessation or prohibition of the infringement immediately.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows the court to make an interim online interface order against a person if it is alleged that there has been or is likely to be a relevant infringement, it would likely grant an application for an online interface order, and it is expedient to immediately stop or prohibit the infringement.

change.subject: section 156
change.quote: 156 Acceptance of undertakings by enforcers (1) 25 This section applies where an enforcer could make an application under section 146 for an enforcement order, or an interim enforcement order, against a person (“the respondent”) whom the enforcer believes— (a) has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice which constitutes a relevant infringement (“the infringing practice”), or (b) is an accessory to the infringing practice. 30
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows an enforcer to accept an undertaking from a respondent if they believe the respondent has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement or if they believe the respondent is an accessory to the infringing practice.

change.subject: section 157
change.quote: 157 Undertakings under section 156: enhanced consumer measures (1) 30 An undertaking under section 156(2) may include a requirement to take such enhanced consumer measures as the enforcer accepting the undertaking considers just and reasonable.
change.summary: The proposed amendment allows an undertaking under section 156(2) to include a requirement to take enhanced consumer measures as determined by the enforcer accepting the undertaking.

change.subject: section 158
change.quote: 158 Undertakings under section 156: procedural requirements 15 (1) This section applies where an enforcer proposes to— (a) accept a material variation of an undertaking under section 156, or (b) release the respondent from any such undertaking.
change.summary: The proposed amendment outlines the procedural requirements that an enforcer must follow when accepting a material variation of an undertaking under section 156 or releasing the respondent from such an undertaking.

change.subject: subsection 30
change.quote: If after considering any representations made in accordance with a notice under subsection (3) an enforcer decides to take an action mentioned in subsection (1), the enforcer must give notice to the respondent of that decision.
change.summary: The amendment requires an enforcer to give notice to the respondent if they decide to take action after considering any representations made in accordance with a notice.

change.subject: subsection 159(1)
change.quote: This section applies if the court— 35 (a) makes a consumer protection order against a person (“the respondent”) on an application made by an enforcer (“the original application”), or (b) accepts an undertaking from the respondent under section 149 or 152 on the making of the original application.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that this section applies if the court makes a consumer protection order against a person or accepts an undertaking from the respondent.

change.subject: subsection 160(2)
change.quote: The enforcer may apply to the court in respect of a failure to comply with the undertaking.
change.summary: The amendment allows the enforcer to apply to the court in respect of a failure to comply with the undertaking.

change.subject: subsection 161(2)
change.quote: The amount of the penalty must be— (a) a fixed amount, (b) an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or (c) a combination of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate.
change.summary: The amendment specifies that the amount of the penalty can be a fixed amount, an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or a combination of both.

change.subject: subsection 162(2)
change.quote: Before making an application for an enforcement order or an interim enforcement order the enforcer— (a) must by notice inform the CMA of its intention to do so, and (b) may only proceed to make the application after expiry of the minimum period or, if sooner, after the CMA has by notice informed the enforcer that it consents to the making of the application.
change.summary: The amendment requires the enforcer to inform the CMA of their intention to make an application for an enforcement order or an interim enforcement order and obtain consent from the CMA before proceeding with the application.

change.subject: subsection 169(1)
change.quote: This section applies if— (a) a court makes a consumer protection order against a body corporate (“the respondent”), and (b) the interconnection condition applies in relation to the respondent.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that this section applies if a court makes a consumer protection order against a body corporate and the interconnection condition applies to the respondent.

change.subject: subsection 170(2)
change.quote: The enforcement order or undertaking may include a requirement for the taking of any enhanced consumer measures only if both of the following conditions are met.
change.summary: The amendment specifies that an enforcement order or undertaking may include a requirement for enhanced consumer measures only if certain conditions are met.

change.subject: subsection 171(2)
change.quote: The court may, for the purpose of considering the application, require a respondent to provide evidence as to the accuracy of any factual claim made as part of a commercial practice of the respondent.
change.summary: The amendment allows the court to require a respondent to provide evidence regarding the accuracy of any factual claim made as part of their commercial practice.

change.subject: Section 173
change.quote: (1) This section applies where the CMA has reasonable grounds for suspecting 30 that— (a) a person has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement, or (b) a person is an accessory to such a practice.
change.summary: The amendment expands the scope of Section 173 to include persons who are accessories to a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement.

change.subject: Section 173
change.quote: (3) Where the CMA conducts an investigation, it may publish a notice which (among other things) may— (a) state its decision to conduct the investigation, (b) 5 summarise the matter under investigation (including the industry sectors affected), (c) identify, so far as possible, the persons under investigation (including whether they are suspected of falling within subsection (1)(a) or (b)), and (d) indicate the timetable for the conduct of the investigation.
change.summary: The amendment allows the CMA to publish a notice when conducting an investigation, which includes stating its decision to conduct the investigation, summarizing the matter under investigation, identifying the persons under investigation, and indicating the timetable for the investigation.

change.subject: Section 174
change.quote: (1) This section applies where— 15 (a) the CMA has started an investigation under section 173 that is continuing, and (b) the condition in subsection (2) is met in respect of any person (“the respondent”) who is subject to the investigation .
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that Section 174 applies when the CMA has started an investigation under Section 173 that is continuing and the condition in subsection (2) is met in respect of the respondent.

change.subject: Section 174
change.quote: (2) The condition in this subsection is met in respect of the respondent if the 20 CMA has reasonable grounds to believe that— (a) the respondent has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice constituting a relevant infringement (“the infringing practice”), or (b) the respondent is an accessory to such a practice.
change.summary: The amendment expands the condition in Section 174 to include respondents who are accessories to a commercial practice constituting a relevant infringement.

change.subject: Section 175
change.quote: (1) This section applies where— (a) the CMA has given to the respondent a provisional infringement notice 30 under section 174, (b) the time for the respondent to make representations to the CMA in accordance with that notice has expired, and (c) 35 after considering such representations (if any), the CMA is satisfied that— (i) the respondent has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice constituting a relevant infringement, or (ii) the respondent is an accessory to such a practice.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that Section 175 applies when the CMA has given a provisional infringement notice to the respondent under Section 174, the time for the respondent to make representations has expired, and the CMA is satisfied that the respondent has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice constituting a relevant infringement or is an accessory to such a practice.

change.subject: Section 176
change.quote: (1) Directions contained in a final infringement notice may include directions requiring the respondent to take such enhanced consumer measures as the CMA considers just and reasonable.
change.summary: The amendment allows the CMA to include directions in a final infringement notice that require the respondent to take enhanced consumer measures.

change.subject: Section 177
change.quote: (1) This section applies where the CMA is satisfied that a person has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that Section 177 applies when the CMA is satisfied that a person has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement.

change.subject: Section 178
change.quote: (2) The CMA may accept an undertaking under this section in connection with that matter from any person whom the CMA believes— (a) has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage in a commercial practice 10 that constitutes a relevant infringement (“the infringing practice”), or (b) is an accessory to such a practice.
change.summary: The amendment expands Section 178 to allow the CMA to accept an undertaking from any person whom the CMA believes has engaged, is engaging, or is likely to engage in a commercial practice that constitutes a relevant infringement or is an accessory to such a practice.

change.subject: Section 179
change.quote: (2) The CMA may not give a final infringement notice or an online interface notice to the person in relation to the matter.
change.summary: The amendment prohibits the CMA from giving a final infringement notice or an online interface notice to a person in relation to a matter if the CMA has accepted an undertaking from that person under Section 178.

change.subject: Section 181
change.quote: (1) This section applies where— (a) the CMA has accepted an undertaking from a person (“the respondent”) under section 178, and (b) the CMA has reasonable grounds to believe that the respondent has 5 failed to comply with one or more of the terms of the undertaking.
change.summary: The amendment clarifies that Section 181 applies when the CMA has accepted an undertaking from a person under Section 178 and has reasonable grounds to believe that the person has failed to comply with one or more of the terms of the undertaking.

change.subject: Section 182
change.quote: (3) A provisional breach of undertakings enforcement notice must also state— (a) that the CMA is considering imposing a monetary penalty; (b) the proposed amount of the penalty (including whether the penalty would be a fixed amount, an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate or both a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate); (c) any further factors (in addition to those provided under subsection (3)(a)) which the CMA considers justify the imposition of the proposed penalty and its amount or amounts.
change.summary: The amendment requires a provisional breach of undertakings enforcement notice to state that the CMA is considering imposing a monetary penalty, the proposed amount of the penalty, and any further factors that the CMA considers justify the imposition of the proposed penalty and its amount or amounts.

change.subject: Section 183
change.quote: (5) A final breach of undertakings enforcement notice must— (a) 25 set out the grounds on which it is given, including the respondent’s acts or omissions giving rise to the failure mentioned in subsection (1)(c); (b) state any further factors (in addition to those provided under paragraph (a)) which the CMA considers justify the giving of the notice; (c) 30 if directions are given under subsection (3)(a), specify the actions to be taken by the respondent in accordance with the directions; (d) if a penalty is imposed under subsection (3)(b), specify the monetary penalty information (see section 196); (e) state that the respondent has a right to appeal against the notice and 35 the main details of that right (so far as not stated in accordance with paragraph (d)).
change.summary: A final breach of undertakings enforcement notice must include specific information such as the grounds for the notice, any additional factors justifying the notice, actions to be taken by the respondent, monetary penalty information, and the respondent's right to appeal.

change.subject: Section 183
change.quote: 183 Monetary penalties under section 182: amount (1) 40 This section applies in relation to a requirement imposed on the respondent to pay a monetary penalty under a final breach of undertakings enforcement notice.
change.summary: This section specifies the application of monetary penalties in relation to a requirement imposed on the respondent to pay a penalty under a final breach of undertakings enforcement notice.

change.subject: Section 184
change.quote: 184 Provisional breach of directions enforcement notice (1) This section applies where— (a) 25 an enforcement direction has been given to a person (“the respondent”), and (b) the CMA has reasonable grounds to believe that the respondent has without reasonable excuse failed to comply with the direction (fully or to any respect).
change.summary: This section applies to cases where an enforcement direction has been given to a person and the CMA has reasonable grounds to believe that the respondent has failed to comply with the direction without reasonable excuse.

change.subject: Section 185
change.quote: 185 Final breach of directions enforcement notice (1) This section applies where— (a) 20 the CMA has given to the respondent a provisional breach of directions enforcement notice under section 184 in respect of a suspected failure to comply with an enforcement direction, (b) the time for the respondent to make representations to the CMA in accordance with that notice has expired, and (c) 25 after considering such representations (if any), the CMA is satisfied that the respondent has, without reasonable excuse, failed to comply with the direction.
change.summary: This section applies to cases where the CMA has given a provisional breach of directions enforcement notice to the respondent in respect of a suspected failure to comply with an enforcement direction, and after considering any representations, the CMA is satisfied that the respondent has failed to comply without reasonable excuse.

change.subject: Section 186
change.quote: 186 Monetary penalties under section 185: amount (1) This section applies in relation to a requirement imposed on the respondent to pay a monetary penalty under a final breach of directions enforcement notice.
change.summary: This section specifies the application of monetary penalties in relation to a requirement imposed on the respondent to pay a penalty under a final breach of directions enforcement notice.

change.subject: Section 187
change.quote: 187 Powers of court to enforce directions (1) This section applies where the CMA considers that a person (“the respondent”) 35 has failed to comply with— (a) an enforcement direction, or (b) a direction given in a final breach of directions enforcement notice under section 185(5)(b).
change.summary: This section applies when the CMA believes that a person has failed to comply with an enforcement direction or a direction given in a final breach of directions enforcement notice.

change.subject: Section 190
change.quote: 190 Provisional false information enforcement notice (1) This section applies if— (a) the CMA has reasonable grounds to believe that a person (“the 25 respondent”) has, without reasonable excuse, provided information to the CMA that is materially false or misleading, and (b) the information was provided in connection with the carrying out by the CMA of a direct enforcement function.
change.summary: This section applies when the CMA believes that a person has provided materially false or misleading information to the CMA in connection with the carrying out of a direct enforcement function.

change.subject: Section 191
change.quote: 191 Final false information enforcement notice (1) This section applies where— (a) 20 the CMA has given to the respondent a provisional false information enforcement notice under section 190 in connection with the provision of information, (b) the time for the respondent to make representations to the CMA in accordance with the notice has expired, and (c) 25 after considering such representations (if any), the CMA is satisfied that— (i) the information mentioned in paragraph (a) is materially false or misleading, and (ii) the respondent provided the false or misleading information without reasonable excuse.
change.summary: This section applies when the CMA has given a provisional false information enforcement notice to the respondent in connection with the provision of false or misleading information, and after considering any representations, the CMA is satisfied that the information is materially false or misleading and was provided without reasonable excuse.

change.subject: Section 192
change.quote: 192 Statement of policy in relation to monetary penalties (1) The CMA must prepare and publish a statement of policy in relation to the exercise of powers to impose a monetary penalty under this Chapter.
change.summary: This section requires the CMA to prepare and publish a statement of policy regarding the exercise of powers to impose monetary penalties under this Chapter.

change.subject: Section 193
change.quote: 193 Interconnected bodies corporate (1) This section applies where— (a) the CMA gives to a body corporate (“the respondent”) a final notice, 25 and (b) the interconnection condition applies in relation to the respondent.
change.summary: This section applies when the CMA gives a final notice to a body corporate and the interconnection condition applies to the respondent.

change.subject: Section 194
change.quote: 194 Record-keeping and reporting requirements (1) The CMA must keep a record of— (a) undertakings it has accepted and enforcement directions it has given, and (b) reviews it has carried out in relation to the effectiveness of such undertakings and directions.
change.summary: This section requires the CMA to keep a record of undertakings it has accepted, enforcement directions it has given, and reviews it has conducted regarding the effectiveness of these undertakings and directions.

change.subject: Section 195
change.quote: 195 Appeals (1) A person to whom a relevant notice is given may appeal to the appropriate appeal court against— (a) a decision to impose a monetary penalty by virtue of the notice, (b) the nature or amount of any such penalty, or 5 (c) the giving of directions by virtue of the notice.
change.summary: This section allows a person who has been given a relevant notice to appeal to the appropriate appeal court against a decision to impose a monetary penalty, the nature or amount of the penalty, or the giving of directions by virtue of the notice.

change.subject: Section 196
change.summary: The amendment requires that an order or notice imposing a monetary penalty must state specific information, including the amount of the penalty, the grounds for the penalty, how the penalty is to be paid, and the rights of the respondent to apply and appeal.

change.subject: Section 197
change.summary: The amendment expands the definition of "turnover" to include turnover both in and outside the United Kingdom, as well as the turnover of controlled and controlling persons.

change.subject: Section 198
change.summary: The amendment grants the Secretary of State the power to amend specific provisions in order to substitute a different monetary amount for a fixed or daily penalty.

change.subject: Section 199
change.quote: This section applies where a monetary penalty imposed under Chapter 4, or 5 any part of such a penalty, has not been paid by the date on which it is required to be paid and— (a) an appeal to a court against the imposition of the penalty has not been brought before the end of the period within which it is required to be brought, or (b) any such appeal that was brought has been determined, withdrawn or otherwise disposed of.
change.summary: The amendment specifies the circumstances in which a monetary penalty that has not been paid by the required date can be subject to recovery by the CMA.

change.subject: Section 201
change.summary: The amendment introduces amendments to Schedule 5 of the CRA 2015 regarding investigatory powers, including the giving of monetary penalties for non-compliance with information notices and the means of giving information notices.

change.subject: Section 202
change.summary: The amendment grants the Secretary of State the power to amend Schedule 13 and Schedule 14, including adding, removing, or varying entries for enactments and authorized enforcers.

change.subject: Section 204
change.quote: The CMA may make rules about procedural and other matters in connection with the carrying out of its direct enforcement functions.
change.summary: The amendment grants the CMA the power to make rules regarding procedural and other matters related to its direct enforcement functions.

change.subject: Section 206
change.quote: The CMA must prepare and publish guidance about its general approach to the carrying out of its direct enforcement functions.
change.summary: The amendment requires the CMA to prepare and publish guidance on its general approach to carrying out its direct enforcement functions.

change.subject: Section 218
change.quote: (1) Unfair commercial practices are prohibited.

(2) The promotion of unfair commercial practices in, or in connection with, a code of conduct by— (a) a person responsible for the content of a code of conduct, or (b) a person responsible for monitoring compliance with a code of conduct, is prohibited.
change.summary: The proposed change introduces a prohibition on unfair commercial practices and the promotion of such practices in connection with a code of conduct.

change.subject: Section 219
change.quote: (1) For the purposes of this Chapter, a commercial practice involves a misleading action if the practice involves— (a) the provision of false or misleading information relating to a product, 40 a trader or any other matter relevant to a transactional decision, (b) an overall presentation which is likely to deceive the average consumer about a matter relating to a product, a trader or any other matter relevant to a transactional decision, (c) any marketing of a product which creates confusion, or is likely to create confusion, with any product, trade mark, trade name or other distinguishing mark of another trader, or (d) a failure to comply with a requirement in a code of conduct to which subsection (5) applies in circumstances where the trader asserts that the trader acts in compliance with that code.
change.summary: The proposed change defines what constitutes a misleading action in commercial practices, including the provision of false or misleading information, deceptive overall presentation, marketing that creates confusion, and failure to comply with a code of conduct.

change.subject: Section 220
change.quote: (1) For the purposes of this Chapter, a commercial practice involves a misleading omission if, considering the matters mentioned in subsection (3), the practice— (a) omits material information, (b) omits information which the trader is required under any other 25 enactment to give to a consumer as part of the practice, or (c) fails to identify its commercial intent (unless it is already apparent from the context).
change.summary: The proposed change defines what constitutes a misleading omission in commercial practices, including the omission of material information, required information, or failure to identify commercial intent.

change.subject: Section 221
change.quote: (1) For the purposes of this Chapter, a commercial practice involves an aggressive practice if it uses harassment, coercion or undue influence.
change.summary: The proposed change defines what constitutes an aggressive practice in commercial practices, including the use of harassment, coercion, or undue influence.

change.subject: Section 222
change.quote: For the purposes of this Chapter, a commercial practice involves a contravention of the requirements of professional diligence if the practice falls short of the standard of skill and care which a trader may reasonably be expected to exercise towards consumers which is commensurate with either— (a) honest market practice in the trader’s field of activity, or (b) the general principle of good faith in the trader’s field of activity.
change.summary: The proposed change defines what constitutes a contravention of the requirements of professional diligence in commercial practices, including falling short of the standard of skill and care expected of a trader in their field of activity.

change.subject: Section 223
change.quote: (1) For the purposes of this Chapter, a commercial practice which is an invitation to purchase omits material information if, considering the matters mentioned in subsection (6), it omits any of the information set out in subsection (2).
change.summary: The proposed change defines what constitutes an omission of material information in an invitation to purchase in commercial practices.

change.subject: Section 224
change.quote: (1) It is the duty of every local weights and measures authority in Great Britain to enforce in its area the prohibitions in section 218. (2) It is the duty of the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland to enforce the prohibitions in section 218 in Northern Ireland. (3) The CMA may also enforce the provisions of this Chapter. (4) In exercising functions under this section, every local weights and measures authority in Great Britain, the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland and the CMA must have regard to the desirability of encouraging control of unfair commercial practices by such established means as it considers appropriate having regard to all the circumstances of the particular case.
change.summary: The proposed change establishes the duties of local weights and measures authorities, the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, and the CMA in enforcing the prohibitions on unfair commercial practices.

change.subject: Section 225(1)
change.quote: (1) A consumer has rights of redress under this Chapter if each of the following four conditions is met.
change.summary: The proposed change amends the conditions under which a consumer has rights of redress.

change.subject: Section 225(2)(a)
change.quote: (2) The first condition is that— (a) the consumer enters into a contract with a trader under which the trader supplies a product to the consumer (a “business-to-consumer contract”),
change.summary: The proposed change clarifies the definition of a business-to-consumer contract.

change.subject: Section 225(2)(b)
change.quote: (b) the consumer enters into a contract with a trader under which— (i) the consumer supplies a product to the trader, and (ii) the trader does not supply a product to the consumer (a “consumer-to-business contract”),
change.summary: The proposed change clarifies the definition of a consumer-to-business contract.

change.subject: Section 225(2)(c)
change.quote: (c) the consumer makes a payment to the trader for the supply of a product (a “consumer payment”).
change.summary: The proposed change clarifies the definition of a consumer payment.

change.subject: Section 226(1)
change.summary: The proposed change grants the Secretary of State the power to provide for different rights of redress for consumers.

change.subject: Section 226(2)(a)
change.quote: (a) about how a right is to be exercised by the consumer;
change.summary: The proposed change allows for regulations to be made regarding how a consumer exercises their rights of redress.

change.subject: Section 226(2)(b)
change.quote: (b) for an amount of discount mentioned in subsection (1)(b) to be determined in accordance with the regulations;
change.summary: The proposed change allows for regulations to determine the amount of discount a consumer is entitled to.

change.subject: Section 226(2)(c)
change.quote: (c) about the circumstances in which damages mentioned in subsection (1)(c) are or are not payable;
change.summary: The proposed change allows for regulations to specify the circumstances in which damages are payable to consumers.

change.subject: Section 226(2)(f)
change.quote: (f) excluding products of a description specified in the regulations from the application of the rights of redress available under this Chapter.
change.summary: The proposed change allows for regulations to exclude certain products from the rights of redress available to consumers.

change.subject: Section 227(1)
change.quote: (1) A consumer with a right to unwind, a right to a discount or a right to damages by virtue of regulations under section 226 may bring a claim in civil proceedings to enforce that right.
change.summary: The proposed change allows consumers to bring civil proceedings to enforce their rights of redress.

change.subject: Section 230(1)
change.quote: (1) A trader commits an offence if, in breach of section 218(1), the trader engages in an unfair commercial practice which involves a misleading action within section 219(1)(a), (b) or (c) (see section 218(4)(a)(i)).
change.summary: The proposed change expands the definition of an offence committed by a trader engaging in an unfair commercial practice involving a misleading action.

change.subject: Section 230(2)
change.quote: (2) A trader commits an offence if, in breach of section 218(1), the trader engages in an unfair commercial practice which involves a misleading omission (see section 218(4)(a)(ii)).
change.summary: The proposed change expands the definition of an offence committed by a trader engaging in an unfair commercial practice involving a misleading omission.

change.subject: Section 230(3)
change.quote: (3) A trader commits an offence if, in breach of section 218(1), the trader engages in an unfair commercial practice which involves an aggressive practice (see section 218(4)(a)(iii)).
change.summary: The proposed change expands the definition of an offence committed by a trader engaging in an unfair commercial practice involving an aggressive practice.

change.subject: Section 230(4)
change.quote: (4) A trader commits an offence if, in breach of section 218(1)— (a) the trader engages in an unfair commercial practice which involves a contravention of the requirements of professional diligence (see section 218(4)(a)(iv)), and (b) the trader knows, or is reckless as to whether, the commercial practice involves a contravention of the requirements of professional diligence.
change.summary: The proposed change expands the definition of an offence committed by a trader engaging in an unfair commercial practice involving a contravention of the requirements of professional diligence.

change.subject: Section 230(6)
change.quote: (6) A trader commits an offence if, in breach of section 218(1), the trader engages in an unfair commercial practice by omitting material information from an invitation to purchase (see section 218(4)(b)).
change.summary: The proposed change expands the definition of an offence committed by a trader engaging in an unfair commercial practice by omitting material information from an invitation to purchase.

change.subject: Section 230(7)

change.subject: Chapter 2—Subscription contracts
change.quote: (1) For the purposes of this Chapter, a subscription contract is a contract between a trader and a consumer— (a) 5 for the supply of goods, services or digital content by the trader to the consumer in exchange for payment by the consumer, (b) to which either or both of subsections (2) and (3) apply, and (c) which is not an excluded contract (see section 248).
change.summary: A subscription contract is defined as a contract between a trader and a consumer for the supply of goods, services, or digital content in exchange for payment by the consumer, subject to subsections (2) and (3), and not being an excluded contract.

change.subject: Chapter 2—Subscription contracts
change.quote: (2) This subsection applies to a contract if it contains terms which have the effect of providing— (a) for an automatically recurring, or continuing, supply of goods, services 10 or digital content to the consumer for an indefinite period or a fixed period, (b) for the consumer to automatically incur liability for each supply, or recurring liabilities for the continuing supply, and (c) a right for the consumer to bring the contract to an end. 15
change.summary: Subsection (2) applies to a contract if it contains terms that provide for an automatically recurring or continuing supply of goods, services, or digital content to the consumer for an indefinite or fixed period, with the consumer automatically incurring liability for each supply or recurring liabilities and having the right to bring the contract to an end.

change.subject: Chapter 2—Subscription contracts
change.quote: (3) This subsection applies to a contract if it contains terms which have the effect of providing— (a) for a supply of goods, services or digital content to a consumer free 20 of charge, or at a rate specified in the contract (the “original rate”), for a period specified in the contract, (b) for the consumer to become automatically liable for payments, or payments at a rate higher than the original rate, for supplies after that period (including where the trader has an option to impose a charge or a higher charge after the end of the period), and (c) a right for the consumer to bring the contract to an end before such 25 liability is incurred.
change.summary: Subsection (3) applies to a contract if it contains terms that provide for a supply of goods, services, or digital content to a consumer free of charge or at a specified rate for a specified period, with the consumer becoming automatically liable for payments or payments at a higher rate after that period, and having the right to bring the contract to an end before incurring such liability.

change.subject: Chapter 2—Subscription contracts
change.quote: (4) In this Chapter, references to a consumer’s right to bring a subscription contract to an end are references to a right provided under the contract which— (a) in the case of a contract for a fixed period, may be exercised to bring 30 the contract to an end before the end of the fixed period; (b) in any case, may be exercised without the consumer incurring any penalty which is more than nominal, 35 and include references to a right that is expressed in terms of a right to stop a subscription contract from automatically renewing or continuing or any other similar expression.
change.summary: References in this Chapter to a consumer's right to bring a subscription contract to an end are references to a right provided under the contract that may be exercised before the end of a fixed period (in the case of a contract for a fixed period) or without incurring a penalty more than nominal (in any case), including a right to stop the contract from automatically renewing or continuing.

change.summary: This Chapter imposes duties on traders in relation to subscription contracts, provides rights for consumers if those duties are breached, and provides rights for consumers to cancel subscription contracts during cooling-off periods.

change.subject: subsection 6
change.quote: (6) Where a subscription contract is cancelled under this section— (a) 10 the cancellation ends both the trader’s and the consumer’s obligations to perform the contract in respect of any rights or liabilities that would arise (but for the cancellation) after the time at which the contract was cancelled, (b) the consumer’s liability for payments that have arisen under the 15 contract is extinguished to any extent set out in regulations under section 260(1)(b) (and, accordingly, the consumer may be entitled to a refund), and (c) any other provision made under those regulations in relation to the treatment of goods, services or digital content supplied under a cancelled subscription contract applies.
change.summary: Subsection 6 of the bill proposes that the cancellation of a subscription contract would end both the trader's and the consumer's obligations to perform the contract in relation to any rights or liabilities that would arise after the cancellation. It also states that the consumer's liability for payments made under the contract would be extinguished to the extent specified in regulations, potentially entitling the consumer to a refund. Additionally, any other provisions made under the regulations regarding the treatment of goods, services, or digital content supplied under a cancelled subscription contract would apply.

change.subject: subsection 7
change.quote: (7) No penalty or charge may be imposed on a consumer for cancelling a 20 subscription contract under subsection (2).
change.summary: Subsection 7 of the bill states that no penalty or charge may be imposed on a consumer for cancelling a subscription contract under subsection 2.

change.subject: subsection 257
change.quote: 257 Right to cancel during cooling-off periods 25 (1) A consumer has the right to cancel a subscription contract during— (a) the initial cooling-off period, and (b) any renewal cooling-off period.
change.summary: Subsection 257 of the bill establishes that a consumer has the right to cancel a subscription contract during both the initial cooling-off period and any renewal cooling-off period.

change.subject: subsection 259
change.quote: (1) 20 In relation to each renewal cooling-off period, a trader must give the consumer a notice (referred to in this Chapter as a “cooling-off notice”).

change.subject: subsection 260

change.summary: Subsection 260 of the bill grants the Secretary of State the power to make regulations regarding the exercise of consumer rights to cancel a subscription contract, the consequences of exercising such rights, and the extension of cooling-off periods as specified in the regulations.

change.subject: subsection 265

change.summary: Subsection 265 of the bill states that if a trader provides information or notice under this Chapter through electronic communication, it is considered to be given by the trader and received by the consumer at the time the communication is sent.

change.subject: subsection 266

change.subject: subsection 267

change.summary: Subsection 267 of the bill clarifies that the provisions of this Chapter do not limit the consumer's ability to seek other remedies for the breach of any term in a subscription contract.

change.subject: subsection 270
change.quote: (1) The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision— (a) about how and when information or a notice that a trader is required to give to a consumer under this Chapter may or must be given; (b) 20 about the information that is to be contained in a notice given under this Chapter; (c) about the arrangements that a trader must make under section 253 to enable a consumer to exercise a right to bring a subscription contract to an end, and about when a consumer may exercise such a right; (d) 25 specifying the period of time within which the refund of an overpayment must be made under section 254(2)(b); (e) specifying descriptions of cases for the purposes of section 266(2) (and about the day on which a contract renews for those purposes).
change.summary: Subsection 270 of the bill grants the Secretary of State the power to make regulations regarding the provision of information or notice by traders to consumers, the content of notices, the arrangements for enabling consumers to exercise their rights, the timeframe for refunding overpayments, and the specification of cases for the purposes of section 266.

change.subject: Chapter 3
change.quote: (275) Meaning of “consumer savings scheme contract” (1) For the purposes of this Chapter, a consumer savings scheme contract is a 25 contract— (a) under which— (i) a consumer makes payments to a trader, (ii) 30 the trader credits those payments to an account that is held by the trader for the consumer (“the consumer’s account”), and (iii) the payments credited to the consumer’s account provide a fund for the consumer to redeem as goods, services or digital content in accordance with the terms of the contract, (b) to which one or more of subsections (2), (3) or (4) applies, and (c) which is not an excluded arrangement (see section 277).
change.summary: The amendment defines a "consumer savings scheme contract" as a contract where a consumer makes payments to a trader, the trader credits those payments to an account held by the trader for the consumer, and the payments provide a fund for the consumer to redeem as goods, services, or digital content. The contract must also meet certain criteria and not be an excluded arrangement.

change.subject: Chapter 3
change.quote: (278) Insolvency protection requirement (1) A trader operating a consumer savings scheme must make and maintain the 10 arrangements set out in section 279 (insurance arrangements) or in section 280 (trust arrangements) to cover, in the event of the trader’s insolvency, the cost of returning to the consumer any protected payments at the time of the insolvency.
change.summary: The amendment states that a trader operating a consumer savings scheme must have arrangements in place to cover the cost of returning protected payments to consumers in the event of the trader's insolvency.

change.subject: Chapter 3
change.quote: (281) Information requirements (1) 10 A trader must, before the end of 30 working days beginning with the day on which a consumer makes the first payment to the trader under a consumer savings scheme contract, provide to the consumer the following information— (a) the name, address, telephone number and email address of the insurer or trustees responsible for protecting the consumer’s payments; (b) 15 where insurance arrangements are in place, the policy number for the policy under which the consumer’s payments are protected; (c) where trust arrangements are in place, a copy of the trust deed under which the consumer’s payments are held.
change.summary: The amendment requires a trader to provide certain information to the consumer before the end of 30 working days after the consumer makes the first payment under a consumer savings scheme contract. The information includes the name, address, telephone number, and email address of the insurer or trustees responsible for protecting the consumer's payments, the policy number if insurance arrangements are in place, and a copy of the trust deed if trust arrangements are in place.

change.subject: Chapter 4
change.quote: (284) Meaning of “ADR” and related terms (1) This section has effect for the purposes of this Chapter. 15 (2) “ADR” means any method of securing or facilitating an out-of-court resolution of a consumer contract dispute that is carried out by an independent third party acting in relation to both parties to the dispute. (3) 20 But the term “ADR” does not include anything carried out by a person in their capacity as— (a) a judge, or (b) a member of the staff of a court or tribunal. (4) The following are examples of ADR (if carried out as mentioned in subsection (2) in relation to a consumer contract dispute)— (a) mediation; 25 (b) arbitration; (c) early neutral evaluation; (d) action under an ombudsman scheme. (5) In subsection (2) “resolution” includes— (a) a decision binding both parties; 30 (b) a decision which, if accepted by the consumer, binds the trader; (c) settlement of the dispute between the parties. (6) “ADR provider” means a person who does either or both of the following— (a) carrying out ADR in relation to a consumer contract dispute, or (b) making special ADR arrangements.
change.summary: The amendment defines "ADR" as any method of securing or facilitating an out-of-court resolution of a consumer contract dispute carried out by an independent third party. It also provides examples of ADR methods and defines "ADR provider" as a person who carries out ADR or makes special ADR arrangements.

change.subject: Section 285(2)

change.subject: Section 286(1)
change.quote: (1) A person must not carry out ADR in relation to a consumer contract dispute unless the person— (a) is an exempt ADR provider whose exemption covers the ADR being carried out, (b) is an accredited ADR provider whose accreditation covers the ADR being carried out, or (c) is acting under special ADR arrangements made by— (i) an exempt ADR provider whose exemption covers the making of those special ADR arrangements, or (ii) an accredited ADR provider whose accreditation covers the making of those special ADR arrangements.
change.summary: This insertion prohibits a person from carrying out Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) in relation to a consumer contract dispute unless they are an exempt or accredited ADR provider or are acting under special ADR arrangements made by an exempt or accredited ADR provider.

change.subject: Section 287(1)
change.quote: (1) An accredited ADR provider must not charge the consumer a fee in respect of ADR being carried out (or to be carried out) in relation to a consumer contract— (a) by the accredited ADR provider, or (b) by another ADR provider under special ADR arrangements made by the accredited ADR provider, unless the fee is charged in accordance with provisions for the charging of fees to consumers which meet the conditions in subsection (2).
change.summary: This insertion prohibits an accredited ADR provider from charging the consumer a fee for ADR services unless the fee is charged in accordance with provisions that meet certain conditions.

change.subject: Section 288(1)
change.quote: (1) In this Chapter— “exempt ADR provider” means a person who— (a) is listed (or of a description of persons listed) in Part 1 of Schedule 22, or (b) is (when carrying out ADR or making special ADR arrangements) acting under or for the purposes of an exempt redress scheme; “exempt redress scheme” means a scheme or other similar arrangement which is listed (or of a description listed) in Part 2 of Schedule 22.

change.subject: Section 300
change.quote: (1) This section applies where a trader responds to a complaint from a consumer in respect of any matters relating to a consumer contract between them.
change.summary: The amendment applies this section to cases where a trader responds to a complaint from a consumer regarding matters related to a consumer contract between them.

change.subject: Section 303
change.quote: (1) A relevant regulator (“R”) may assist an overseas regulator (“O”) in accordance with the table in subsection (2) where— (a) O makes a request to R (see section 304) for R to assist O’s carrying out of functions— (i) which correspond or are similar to functions of R under a relevant enactment, but (ii) which are not functions relating to the investigation of crime or the bringing of criminal proceedings, (b) R considers that it would be appropriate to assist O (see section 305), and (c) the Secretary of State authorises R to assist O (see section 306).
change.summary: The amendment allows a relevant regulator to assist an overseas regulator in carrying out functions that correspond or are similar to the functions of the relevant regulator, as long as the Secretary of State authorizes it.

change.subject: subsection 2 of section 305
change.quote: (2) In considering whether it would be appropriate to assist O, R must have regard to whether— (a) R would be able to exercise its powers under the relevant enactment 25 concerned in a corresponding or similar case arising in the United Kingdom; (b) the United Kingdom and the country or territory of O, or R and O, 30 are parties to any agreements or arrangements relating in whole or in part to cooperation in matters relating to competition or consumer protection; (c) the matter in respect of which the assistance is requested is sufficiently serious to justify R assisting O.
change.summary: Subsection 2 of section 305 is being amended to provide guidance on the factors that R must consider when determining whether it would be appropriate to assist O. These factors include the ability to exercise powers in a corresponding case in the UK, the existence of agreements or arrangements between the UK and O, and the seriousness of the matter in question.

change.subject: subsection 4 of section 305
change.quote: (4) R must consider that it would not be appropriate to assist O if R considers that— (a) 40 a person or body in the country or territory of O (whether or not O) would not provide corresponding assistance to R, unless R considers Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Bill 207 Part 5—Miscellaneous Chapter 1—Provision of investigative assistance to overseas regulators that there is an overriding public benefit to the United Kingdom in assisting O; (b) R would not be able to disclose, under Part 9 of EA 2002 (information), to O any information obtained by R in the course of assisting O; (c) assisting O would be contrary to the public interest.
change.summary: Subsection 4 of section 305 is being amended to specify that R must consider it inappropriate to assist O if there is no corresponding assistance provided by the country or territory of O, if R cannot disclose information obtained in the course of assisting O, or if assisting O would be contrary to the public interest.

change.subject: section 306
change.quote: (1) This section makes provision about how the Secretary of State authorises R 20 to assist O for the purposes of section 303(1)(c). (2) The Secretary of State may authorise R to assist O either— (a) in relation to one or more specific requests for assistance, or (b) 25 generally in respect of requests for assistance of a particular description (including in respect of requests from particular overseas regulators). (3) The Secretary of State may withdraw any general authorisation given under subsection (2)(b). (4) The Secretary of State must publish— (a) any general authorisation given under subsection (2)(b); (b) notice of any withdrawal of a general authorisation under subsection 30 (3).
change.summary: Section 306 is being amended to outline the process by which the Secretary of State authorizes R to assist O. The Secretary of State can provide authorization for specific requests or for requests of a particular description. The Secretary of State is also required to publish any general authorizations and any withdrawals of such authorizations.

(2) The information must not be used by the overseas public authority other than for facilitating the exercise by the discloser of the original function in relation to the original matter unless— (a) the use is for the purpose of facilitating the exercise by the discloser of any function it has under this Act or any other enactment (other than the original function) whether or not in relation to the original matter, and (b) the discloser consents to the use of that information for that 25 purpose. change.subject: section 315
change.quote: "315 Regulations (1) A power to make regulations under any provision of this Act includes power to make— (a) consequential, supplementary, incidental, transitional or saving provision; (b) different provision for different purposes. (2) Regulations under this Act are to be made by statutory instrument. change.summary: A new section 315 is being inserted, which provides for the power to make regulations under the Act, including consequential, supplementary, incidental, transitional, or saving provisions, and different provisions for different purposes. change.subject: section 317
change.quote: "317 Commencement (1) Except as provided by subsection (2), this Act come into force on such day 35 as the Secretary of State may by regulations appoint. (3) Different days may be appointed under subsection (1) for different purposes. change.summary: A new section 317 is being inserted, which provides for the commencement of the Act. It states that the Act will come into force on a day appointed by the Secretary of State, except for certain provisions that come into force on the day the Act is passed. It also allows for different commencement dates for different purposes and for the Secretary of State to make transitional or saving provisions in connection with the coming into force of any provision.

(3) In this section and in sections 34ZE and 34ZF, “fast-track reference request” means a request that the CMA makes a reference under section 22(1A) or 33(1A) in relation to the arrangements concerned. 34ZE Fast-track reference requests: procedure (1) This section applies where a fast-track reference request is made and not withdrawn. (2) Where the fast-track reference request is made before the beginning of the initial period, the CMA may, at any time before the beginning of that period, reject the request. (3) Where the CMA has not rejected the fast-track reference request in accordance with subsection (2), the CMA must, within the decision period, decide whether to accept the request in accordance with section 34ZF or reject the request. (4) Where the CMA accepts or rejects a fast-track reference request, the CMA must notify the persons carrying on the enterprises concerned that the request has been accepted or rejected. (5) In this section— “decision period” means, in relation to the arrangements concerned— (a) in a case where the initial period has not begun, that period, or (b) in a case where the initial period has begun, the period beginning with the day on which the fast-track reference request is made and ending at the end of the initial period; “initial period” has the meaning given by section 34ZA(3). 34ZF Acceptance by the CMA of fast-track reference requests (1) The CMA may accept a fast-track reference request only if the condition in subsection (2) or (3) is met. (2) The condition in this subsection is that, in relation to the arrangements concerned— (a) the CMA believes that it is or may be the case that a relevant merger situation has been created, and (b) the CMA would not be prevented from making a reference under section 22(1) by reason of section 22(3). (3) The condition in this subsection is that, in relation to the arrangements concerned— (a) the CMA believes that it is or may be the case that, if carried into effect, the arrangements will result in the creation of a relevant merger situation, and (b) the CMA would not be prevented from making a reference under section 33(1) by reason of section 33(3). (4) In deciding whether to accept a fast-track reference request under subsection (2) or (3), the CMA must have regard, in particular, to— (a) whether the arrangements concerned raise any consideration specified in section 58; (b) whether a special intervention notice (see section 59(2)) is in force in relation to the arrangements. (5) Where the CMA decides to accept a fast-track reference request the duties to make references under sections 22(1) and 33(1) do not apply, and accordingly the CMA may not make any reference under those provisions in respect of the arrangements concerned (but see the duties under sections 22(1A) and 33(1A)).”
change.summary: The amendment inserts a new Schedule 5 into EA 2002, which introduces provisions for fast-track references under sections 22 and 33. It specifies the duties of the CMA to make references in relation to completed and anticipated mergers, sets time-limits for decisions about references, and outlines the procedure for fast-track reference requests. It also provides criteria for the acceptance of fast-track reference requests by the CMA.

(4) The relevant authority begins an implementation trial by— (a) accepting, from such persons as the relevant authority considers appropriate, undertakings under this section to take action specified or described in the undertakings, or (b) making an order under this section, for the purposes of assessing, during the implementation trial period, the likely effectiveness of the qualifying remedial action.

change.subject: Section 35A (enforcement of powers under sections 31A, 32, 33 and 35)
change.quote: “(1) The CMA may impose a penalty on a person in accordance with section 35B where the CMA considers that—
(a) a person from whom the CMA has accepted commitments under section 31A has, without reasonable excuse, failed to adhere to the commitments (and has not been released from them);
(b) a person has, without reasonable excuse, failed to comply with a direction under section 32, 33 or 35.”

(2) In deciding whether and, if so, how to proceed under subsection (1) the CMA must have regard to the statement of policy which was most recently published under section 35C at the time of the failure to adhere or comply.
(35B) A penalty under section 35A(1) is to be such amount as the CMA considers appropriate.
(35B) The amount must be—
(a) a fixed amount,
(b) an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or
(c) a combination of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate.
(35B) A penalty imposed under section 35A(1) on a person who is not an undertaking must not—
(a) in the case of a fixed amount, exceed £30,000;
(b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed £15,000 per day;
(c) in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed such fixed amount and such amount per day.
(35B) A penalty imposed under section 35A(1) on a person who is an undertaking must not—
(a) in the case of a fixed amount, exceed 5% of the total value of the turnover of the undertaking;
(b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed 5% of the total value of the daily turnover of the undertaking;
(c) in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed such fixed amount and such amount per day.
(35B) In imposing a penalty by reference to a daily rate—

(a) no account is to be taken of any days before the service on the person concerned of the provisional penalty notice under section 112(A1) of the Enterprise Act 2002 (as applied by subsection (6)), and

(b) unless the CMA determines an earlier date (whether before or after the penalty is imposed), the amount payable ceases to accumulate at the beginning of the day on which the person adheres to the commitments or complies with the direction (as the case may be) referred to in section 35A(1).

(35B) Sections 112 to 115 of the Enterprise Act 2002 apply in relation to a penalty imposed under section 35A(1) as they apply in relation to a penalty imposed under section 110(1) or (1A) of that Act, with the following modifications—
(a) any reference in those provisions to the appropriate authority is to be read as a reference to the CMA only;
(b) section 114(5A) is to be read as if the words “In the case of a penalty imposed on a person by the CMA or OFCOM,” were omitted;
(c) section 114(12) is to be read as if, for paragraph (b), there were substituted—
“(b) “relevant guidance” means the statement of policy which was most recently published under section 35C at the time when the act or omission concerned occurred.”

(35B) The Secretary of State may by regulations amend subsection (3)(a) and (b) by substituting for either or both of the sums for the time being specified in those paragraphs such other sum or sums as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.
(35B) Before making regulations under subsection (7) the Secretary of State must consult—
(a) the CMA, and
(b) such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.
(35B) The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for determining the turnover and daily turnover of an undertaking for the purposes of subsection (4).
(35B) Regulations under subsection (9) may, in particular, make provision as to—
(a) the amounts which are, or which are not, to be treated as comprising an undertaking’s turnover or daily turnover;
(b) the date, or dates, by reference to which an undertaking’s turnover, or daily turnover, is to be determined.
change.summary: The amendments introduce Section 35A (enforcement of powers under sections 31A, 32, 33 and 35) and Section 35B (penalties under section 35A) to provide for the imposition of penalties for failure to adhere to commitments or comply with directions. The amount of the penalty is determined by the CMA and can be a fixed amount, an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or a combination of both. The maximum penalty amounts are specified based on whether the person is an undertaking or not. The amendments also provide for the application of Sections 112 to 115 of the Enterprise Act 2002 to penalties imposed under section 35A, with modifications, and allow the Secretary of State to amend the maximum penalty amounts and make regulations for determining turnover and daily turnover.

(3) The CMA may revise its statement of policy and, where it does so, it must publish the revised statement.

change.summary: The amendments introduce Section 35C (statement of policy in relation to functions under sections 31E, 34 and 35A) to require the CMA to prepare and publish a statement of policy regarding the exercise of its functions under these sections. The statement must include considerations relevant to the determination of the nature and amount of any penalty imposed under section 35A(1). change.subject: Section 94AA (enforcement of undertakings and orders)
change.quote: “(1) The appropriate authority may impose a penalty on a person in accordance with section 94AB where the appropriate authority considers that a person has, without reasonable excuse, failed to comply with an enforcement undertaking or enforcement order.
(2) In this section and in section 94AB, “the appropriate authority” means—

(3) In deciding whether and, if so, how to proceed under subsection (1) the CMA must have regard to the statement of policy which was most recently published under section 94B at the time of the failure to comply.
(94AB) A penalty under section 94AA(1) is to be such amount as the appropriate authority considers appropriate.
(94AB) The amount must be—
(a) a fixed amount,
(b) an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or
(c) a combination of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate.
(94AB) A penalty imposed under section 94AA(1) on a person who does not own or control an enterprise must not—
(a) in the case of a fixed amount, exceed £30,000;
(b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed £15,000;
(c) in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed such fixed amount and such amount per day.
(94AB) A penalty imposed under section 94AA(1) on any other person must not—
(a) in the case of a fixed amount, exceed 5% of the total value of the turnover (both in and outside the United Kingdom) of the enterprises owned or controlled by the person on whom it is imposed;

(b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed 5% of the total value of the daily turnover (both in and outside the United Kingdom) of the enterprises owned or controlled by the person on whom it is imposed;
(c) in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed such fixed amount and such amount per day.
(94AB) In imposing a penalty by reference to a daily rate—
(a) no account is to be taken of any days before the service on the person concerned of the provisional penalty notice under section 112(A1) (as applied by subsection (6)), and

(b) unless the CMA determines an earlier date (whether before or after the penalty is imposed), the amount payable ceases to accumulate at the beginning of the day on which the person complies with the enforcement undertaking or enforcement order.
(94AB) Sections 112 to 115 apply in relation to a penalty imposed under section 94AA(1) as they apply in relation to a penalty imposed under section 110(1) or (1A), with the following modifications—
(a) any reference in those provisions to the appropriate authority is to be read as a reference to the appropriate authority within the meaning of this section (see section 94AA(2));
(b) section 114(5A) is to be read as if the words “or OFCOM” were omitted;
(c) section 114(12) is to be read as if, for paragraph (b), there were substituted—
“(b) “relevant guidance” means the statement of policy which was most recently published under section 94B at the time when the act or omission concerned occurred.”

(94AB) The Secretary of State may by regulations amend subsection (3)(a) and (b) by substituting for either or both of the sums for the time being specified in those paragraphs such other sum or sums as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.
(94AB) Before making regulations under subsection (7) the Secretary of State must consult—
(a) the CMA, and
(b) such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.
(94AB) The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for determining, for the purposes of this section—
(a) when an enterprise is to be treated as being controlled by a person;

change.summary: The amendments introduce Section 94AA (enforcement of undertakings and orders) and Section 94AB (penalties under section 94AA) to provide for the imposition of penalties for failure to comply with an enforcement undertaking or enforcement order. The appropriate authority, which can be the Secretary of State or the CMA depending on the case, may impose a penalty on a person without reasonable excuse. The amount of the penalty is determined by the appropriate authority and can be a fixed amount, an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or a combination of both. The maximum penalty amounts are specified based on whether the person owns or controls an enterprise or not. The amendments also provide for the application of Sections 112 to 115 of the Enterprise Act 2002 to penalties imposed under section 94AA, with modifications, and allow the Secretary of State to amend the maximum penalty amounts and make regulations for determining turnover and daily turnover.

change.subject: Section 167B Penalties under section 167A: amount
change.quote: (1) A penalty under section 167A(1) is to be such amount as the relevant 10 authority considers appropriate. (2) The amount must be— (a) a fixed amount, (b) an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or (c) a combination of a fixed amount and an amount calculated 15 by reference to a daily rate. (3) A penalty imposed under section 167A(1) on a person who does not own or control an enterprise must not— (a) in the case of a fixed amount, exceed £30,000; (b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily 20 rate, exceed £15,000 per day; (c) in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed such fixed amount and such amount per day. (4) A penalty imposed under section 167A(1) on any other person must 25 not— (a) in the case of a fixed amount, exceed 5% of the total value of the turnover (both in and outside the United Kingdom) of the enterprises owned or controlled by the person on whom it is imposed; (b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, exceed 5% of the total value of the daily turnover (both in and outside the United Kingdom) of the enterprises owned or controlled by the person on whom it is imposed; (c) in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by 35 reference to a daily rate, exceed such fixed amount and such amount per day. change.summary: A new Section 167B is inserted to provide guidelines for determining the amount of penalties imposed under Section 167A. The amount can be a fixed amount, an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, or a combination of both. The maximum amount of the penalty depends on whether the person owns or controls an enterprise and is subject to certain percentages of turnover or daily turnover.

change.subject: subsection 5
change.quote: (5) The penalty must not exceed— (a) in the case of a fixed amount, £30,000 or, if higher, 1% of 40 the total value of the turnover (if any) of the respondent; Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Bill 321 Schedule 15—Investigatory powers (b) in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, £15,000 per day or, if higher, 5% of the total value of the daily turnover (if any) of the respondent; (c) 5 in the case of a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, such fixed amount and such amount per day.
change.summary: The amendment sets the maximum penalty amounts for violations. The penalty must not exceed £30,000 or 1% of the total value of the respondent's turnover, whichever is higher, for fixed amount penalties. For penalties calculated by a daily rate, the maximum penalty is £15,000 per day or 5% of the total value of the daily turnover, whichever is higher. For penalties that combine a fixed amount and a daily rate, both amounts are subject to the maximum limit.

change.subject: subsection 6
change.quote: (6) In imposing a penalty by reference to a daily rate— (a) no account is to be taken of any days before the date on which the provisional enforcement notice mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(a) was given to the respondent, and (b) unless the CMA determines an earlier date, the amount payable ceases to accumulate on the day on which the requirements of the notice under paragraph 14 are complied with.
change.summary: This amendment specifies the calculation of penalties imposed by a daily rate. The penalty does not include any days before the date the provisional enforcement notice was given to the respondent. The amount payable stops accumulating on the day the requirements of the notice under paragraph 14 are met, unless the CMA determines an earlier date.

change.subject: subsection 7
change.quote: (7) A final enforcement notice that imposes a penalty on the 15 respondent must state— (a) the amount of the penalty (including whether it is a fixed amount, an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate 20 or both a fixed amount and an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate); (b) the grounds on which the penalty is imposed together with any other factors that the CMA considers justify the giving of the penalty or its amount; (c) 25 in the case of an amount calculated by reference to a daily rate, the day on which the amount first starts to accumulate and the day or days on which it might cease to accumulate; (d) how the penalty is to be paid to the CMA; (e) 30 the date or dates, no earlier than the end of 28 days beginning with the date of service of the notice on the respondent, by which the penalty or (as the case may be) different portions of it are required to be paid; (f) that the penalty or (as the case may be) different portions 35 of it may be paid earlier than the date or dates by which it or they are required to be paid; (g) that the respondent has the right to apply under sub-paragraph (8), or to appeal under paragraph 16D, and the main details of those rights.
change.summary: This amendment outlines the information that must be included in a final enforcement notice that imposes a penalty on the respondent. This includes the amount of the penalty, the grounds for the penalty, the start and end dates for the accumulation of the penalty, the payment details, the deadline for payment, the possibility of early payment, and the respondent's rights to apply or appeal.

(1) 324 Digital Markets, Competition and Consumers Bill Schedule 15—Investigatory powers (2) Where an application has been made under paragraph 16A(8) or 16C(8), the penalty is not required to be paid until the application has been determined, withdrawn or otherwise disposed of. change.subject: Definition of "post commencement conduct" and "pre-commencement conduct"
change.quote: “post commencement conduct” means so much of a person’s continuing conduct as takes place on or after the commencement date; “pre-commencement conduct” means so much of a person’s continuing conduct as takes place before the commencement date.
change.summary: The bill proposes to define "post commencement conduct" and "pre-commencement conduct" in relation to a person's continuing conduct.

change.subject: Enforcement action in respect of a person's breach of the undertaking
change.quote: Enforcement action in respect of a person’s breach of the undertaking, whether the breach takes place before, on or after the commencement date, may be taken only under the old law.
change.summary: The bill proposes that enforcement action in respect of a person's breach of the undertaking can only be taken under the old law, regardless of when the breach takes place.

change.subject: Enforcement action in respect of the act or omission
change.quote: Enforcement action in respect of the act or omission may be taken— (a) under the new law, or (b) if the act or omission would also be a domestic or Schedule 13 infringement for the purposes of the old law, under the old law.
change.summary: The bill proposes that enforcement action in respect of the act or omission can be taken under the new law or, if applicable, under the old law.

change.subject: Information notices under Schedule 5 to CRA 2015
change.quote: The amendments made by paragraph 2(3) of Schedule 15 (which insert new paragraphs 16A to 16I into Schedule 5 to CRA 2015) have effect only in relation to an information notice given on or after the commencement date.
change.summary: The bill proposes that the amendments made to Schedule 5 to CRA 2015 will only have effect in relation to information notices given on or after the commencement date.

change.subject: Further provision
change.quote: Nothing in this Schedule limits the power under section 317(4) to make further transitional and saving provision in connection with the coming into force of the new law.
change.summary: The bill proposes that the power to make further transitional and saving provision in connection with the coming into force of the new law is not limited by this Schedule.
